title.value: Towards a unified XAI-based framework for digital forensic investigations
title.justification: The title is explicitly stated at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Towards a unified XAI-based framework for digital forensic investigations

extractions.description: This paper proposes a holistic, unified framework for incorporating Explainable AI (XAI) in digital forensic investigations. It introduces the XAI-DF framework, conducts a case study on network forensics, and initiates a memory forensics database for further research in the XAI-DF domain.

type.justification: The paper presents case studies and implementations of an XAI framework in memory and network forensics, making it an empirical study.
type.quote: A case study examining the implementation of the framework in a network forensics investigative scenario is presented for demonstration.

name.justification: The paper focuses on the application of Explainable AI within the Digital Forensics domain.
name.quote: XAI helps demonstrate a model’s ‘impartiality in decision-making’, by identifying how the prediction was made ... especially in the field of Digital Forensics (DF).

name.justification: Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) is a core concept throughout the paper, as it emphasizes on providing understandable explanations for AI models in digital forensics.
name.quote: Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) aims to alleviate the black-box AI conundrum in the field of Digital Forensics (DF) ...

name.justification: The paper mentions using Decision Trees as a model for AI in digital forensics.
name.quote: a fitting AI model (like Decision Tree, Random Forest, Neural Networks...) that is suitable and compatible with the subject dataset is identified.

is_contributed.justification: Decision Trees are mentioned but were not introduced by this paper as new contributions.
is_contributed.quote: Decision Trees (DT) may especially be used for well-structured forensic data.

is_executed.justification: Decision Trees were implemented as part of the classification processes.
is_executed.quote: Loading the training and testing sets’ CSV files using Pandas ... A DT classifier was then defined and trained.

is_compared.justification: Decision Trees were compared with other models in terms of accuracy and performance.
is_compared.quote: Classification of the memory database ... using Weka’s DT (J48), DT (LMT), DT (Hoeffding), Random Forest, and Naive Bayes...

referenced_paper_title.value: Why Should I Trust You?: Explaining the Predictions of Any Classifier
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper by Ribeiro et al. is cited as a method for explanations in models which the Decision Tree classification relates to as part of the discussed XAI methods.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Ribeiro, M.T., Singh, S., Guestrin, C., 2016. “Why Should I Trust You?”: Explaining the Predictions of Any Classifier.

name.justification: Random Forest is listed as a model used within forensic analysis in this paper.
name.quote: a fitting AI model (like Decision Tree, Random Forest, Neural Networks...) that is suitable and compatible with the subject dataset is identified.

is_contributed.justification: Random Forest was utilized within the paper but is a pre-existing model.
is_contributed.quote: Random Forest (RF) may especially be used for well-structured forensic data.

is_executed.justification: The paper reports on performances and precision using Random Forest for classification tasks.
is_executed.quote: Classification of the memory database ... using Weka’s DT (J48), DT (LMT), DT (Hoeffding), Random Forest, and Naive Bayes...

is_compared.justification: Random Forest has been numerically compared with other models for accuracy and performance.
is_compared.quote: ...Random Forest, and Naive Bayes gave accuracy scores of 93.75 %, 94.55 ..., and Naive Bayes...

referenced_paper_title.value: The significant features of the UNSW-NB15 and the KDD99 data sets for network intrusion detection systems
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference discusses significant features which are applicable to models like Random Forest, often utilized to classify data drawn from these sets.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Moustafa, N., Slay, J., 2015b. The significant features of the UNSW-NB15 and the KDD99 data sets...

name.justification: The paper indicates the use of neural networks in its framework.
name.quote: a fitting AI model (like Decision Tree, Random Forest, Neural Networks...) that is suitable and compatible with the subject dataset is identified.

is_contributed.justification: The Neural Network model was used, not introduced in the paper.
is_contributed.quote: Neural Networks, Support Vector Machines, Gradient Boosting Machines...

is_executed.justification: Neural Networks have been executed as part of the classification process.
is_executed.quote: ...TensorFlow library; DT, RF, and DNN models were used.

is_compared.justification: Neural Networks were part of the comparison studies particularly in memory and network data analysis.
is_compared.quote: Accuracy scores for DT, RF, and DNN models were 93.11 %, 95.28 %, and 93.47 % respectively.

referenced_paper_title.value: The significant features of the UNSW-NB15 and the KDD99 data sets for network intrusion detection systems
referenced_paper_title.justification: Network data features which are integral for Neural Networks training are relevant to the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The significant features of UNSW-NB15...for network intrusion detection systems.

name.justification: UNSW-NB15 is explicitly mentioned as being used within the case study in the article for network attack classification.
name.quote: A case study implementing the practical workflow of the XAI-DF framework (utilizing the UNSW-NB15 network database) is presented.

referenced_paper_title.value: UNSW-NB15: a comprehensive data set for network intrusion detection systems (UNSW-NB15 network data set)
referenced_paper_title.justification: The UNSW-NB15 is a known dataset for network intrusion detection, as detailed in the prior research section.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Moustafa, N., Slay, J., 2015a. UNSW-NB15: a comprehensive data set for network intrusion detection systems (UNSW-NB15 network data set)

name.justification: The paper contributes this particular dataset within the XAI-DF project, creating and detailing a memory forensics database for malware activity.
name.quote: In addition, we extract process-centric memory features from the dumps for explained classification.

referenced_paper_title.value: The Volatility Foundation - Open Source Memory Forensics
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper serves as a foundational reference for memory forensic analysis.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Volatility, 2024. The Volatility Foundation - Open Source Memory Forensics [WWW Document].

name.justification: TensorFlow is explicitly used in the implementation of the framework discussed in the paper.
name.quote: The classification was also done using Python’s TensorFlow library; DT, RF, and DNN models were used.

referenced_paper_title.value: “Why Should I Trust You?”: Explaining the Predictions of Any Classifier
referenced_paper_title.justification: The use of TensorFlow relates back to methods of explaining AI classification as indicated in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Ribeiro, M.T., Singh, S., Guestrin, C., 2016. “Why Should I Trust You?”: Explaining the Predictions of Any Classifier.

name.justification: Weka is explicitly mentioned as being used for classifications in its experimental procedures.
name.quote: Classification of the memory database (Memory_Featur-es_Combined_CSV.csv) using Weka’s DT (J48), DT (LMT), DT (Hoeffding), Random Forest, and Naive Bayes...

referenced_paper_title.quote: Moustafa, N., Slay, J., 2015b. The significant features of the UNSW-NB15 and the KDD99 data sets...

name.justification: Pandas is used for data manipulation during preprocessing in the experimental workflow.
name.quote: Loading the training and testing sets’ CSV files using Pandas, preprocessing steps included combining the datasets...

referenced_paper_title.value: Explainable artificial intelligence for digital forensics
referenced_paper_title.justification: Referenced as a resource closely connected with data handling and XAI implementations.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Hall, S.W., Sakzad, A., Choo, K.R., 2021. Explainable artificial intelligence for digital forensics.

name.justification: NumPy was utilized for numerical computation in the dataset processing phase.
name.quote: In addition, other libraries were used including Pandas for data manipulation, NumPy for numerical computations...

referenced_paper_title.justification: NumPy's utilization is well-aligned in contexts discussing comprehensive data manipulation which supports XAI environments as seen in referenced papers.
